text: It's really good to see you all coming back from your tea and So obviously that's an interesting topic for everyone So let's get started We only have 30 minutes There are all the talks following mention AI at some point So that was my contribution today So without further ado I know Liz has asked that question initially during her keynote but can I get a raise of How many of you are like day to day involved with Kubernetes and you know operating clusters Okay cool Decent crowd like most of you So obviously the right audience So if we quickly start you know you obviously said you're managing Kubernetes clusters but you're probably aware that one of the most kind of common issues that you would see on a or like the one that's the most popular one is probably the crash loop back off Obviously it doesn't tell you much It can be multiple things that's happening there There might be other ones that you see operating clusters as well such as this one So you have a bunch of bots which are just waiting to be scheduled and in the pending state It can mean many things Obviously it's not necessarily related to scaling but by talking about auto scaling solutions today I hope you're going to address at least some of that I mean obviously if you kind of dive into that more you could figure out more details but what I actually found during my kind of you know experience working with clusters is that errors are not usually very kind of self explanatory even by using AI You cannot really tell what's happening unless you really kind of dive deep and understand what's And by using something like Carpenter I hope at least some of you will kind of you I'm not trying to convince you but I hope you're going to see it's a really good solution to kind of avoid at least some of those issues right Right So maybe first of all while I'm here I'm talking about Carpenter You know what experience do I have Like Josh said I'm Marco I work as a principal consultant at a company called ScaleFactory We used to be a smaller consultancy company recently acquired by a larger one called 1010 so we're part of that group My background is mostly ops so I come from infrastructure all the good stuff like we heard in previous sessions like I used to run Puppet I used to run Chef so kind of familiar with that And kind of throughout my career with industry I progress into you know different roles My consultancy gig led me through working with different companies across different kind of industries And I was wearing different hats as part of that And of course as part of the journey I got involved with a lot of like different cluster configurations and kind of cluster errors that people kind of face I'm also an open source contributor You can find me in a cloud native space I'm one of the Helm chart maintainers I also took on the AWS Vault fork active fork that we're currently maintaining And I'm also an active supporter and maintainer of some other projects as well As part of that I'm a Chrome Ambassador Probably not the most popular title these I'm also open you can invest there and community builders from AWS When I'm not doing all of that I'm fan of automation simplifying hiking and traveling So yeah another reason why I'm actually telling you this You've probably seen that picture like a million times already But we are actually part of that ecosystem We're right there this little small square So ScaleFactory is also one of the certified Kubernetes providers Sorry service Kubernetes providers Yes I have to read it So one of the reasons why I'm actually talking about that today as well Right So let's kind of you know switch gears Start from the beginning If you look at the types of scaling you can do in obviously there are different types of resources you can You can scale pods You can scale nodes And there are other resources that probably are not typical resources to but they're like storage and network that you have to manage as well Today I want to focus mostly on scaling nodes not And there are a couple of types of scaling you can do both nodes as well as So you can vertically scale So if you're vertically scaling you're literally making resource bigger or smaller But it means that you're taking the unit of compute and you're just vertically kind of making it bigger or A different type of scaling is horizontal scaling where you have a type of compute And instead of making it bigger or smaller you're actually adding more of the same So you can add one more or three or more So those are kind of basic types of and basically what we're going to address today Something to keep in mind I hope you're aware of that in Kubernetes even though it has support for it doesn't come with auto scaling out of the So when you spin up a fresh Kubernetes cluster it doesn't scale You can obviously add manually computes but it won't scale it automatically and it won't take it away So something to keep in mind Right So if we continue along that line and talk a little bit more about scaling challenges that you can face scaling Kubernetes cluster is So for example what you usually face when you don't have an auto scaling solution in place is something like maybe pending pods with no matching capacity what we've seen earlier when I showed the error So you have pods and there is no capacity that actually those pods could be scheduled on which could be a problem and might involve some either manual intervention if you don't have auto scaling or might take you know auto scaler to pick things up and make sure that there's enough capacity available You could kind of hit a situation where you have to over provision So there might be different reasons why you want to over provision either to avoid the first thing that I mentioned or for example let's say you have spike events when you know there's going to be a huge spike in the load So you might actually want to over provision your capacity to make sure that your pods can actually scale up sufficiently quick to kind of fill that demand Also another typical scaling issue would be lack of flexibility So for example when you scale you have to accommodate for different types of workloads So for example if you're mixing different types of compute classes or like spot instances on demand instances or like GPUs for AI training most of the auto scalers wouldn't have that flexibility out of the box So some of the existing scaling solutions would address some of those things So for example and this is not a take on cluster auto scaler but I'm just using it as an example because it's supposed to be like the most used auto scaler out there Those solutions tend to kind of try to address some of those issues So for example cluster auto scaler would work on the node group level but unfortunately because it doesn't work on the pod level you don't get the flexibility that you might actually want and the actually bin packing that you get with the pods being scheduled on different nodes is sub optimal So you have some more provision capacity left There might be slow reaction times as well So when you kind of have this kind of quick bursts of scaling events both cluster auto scaler or similar solutions might need long time to kind of ramp up the capacity so your pods get scheduled And maintaining that might be complex or might take you know very intense kind of operational overhead to kind of maintain that and make sure that you're either upgrading it or making sure that you're adopting configurations based on your workloads So what's the price of efficiency we're paying here literally So what I've actually mentioned throughout the problems that were kind of laid out earlier is you end up with operational overhead So by maintaining the cluster you're spending more engineering that you probably want to So unless you know you're working in communities development probably maybe you shouldn't be spending your engineering power in maintaining and making sure that your clusters can scale It might be really hard to detect and manage drift So what could happen as well is maybe your configuration comes out of sync with your you know actually provision capacity So that might be harder to detect and manage from those auto scalers And that could lead to like I mentioned earlier basic compute So you either have over provision compute or you know over underutilized compute where you cannot actually fit all the ports in but they still need to be scheduled somewhere right And consequentially you kind of end up with higher costs right So in order to run this it would cost you more because the compute is just underutilized And again what we do at ScaleFactory we mostly work with SAS based companies And in SAS work you would usually end up with multi tenancy problem as well which kind of adds additional layer of complexity where you need to accommodate different requirements for different tenants within the same system And that just makes it so much harder right It's just kind of exponentially gross in terms of So the question here is really you know what can you do to kind of address all this kind of argument today would be you should definitely consider or at least look at something like Carpenter which is an open source node lifecycle management solution It was developed by AWS as part of the AWS labs but it was donated to CNCF I think a year back if I'm not mistaken something like that So it is part of CNCF now And since then it has actually quite wide adoption throughout the ecosystem So there is a provider obviously for AWS as well as Azure IBM Cloud Alibaba GCP There is a start to There is a reason for that Even though it has been released a few months back they haven't had a final release yet but the code base is in active development So if you're on GCP you can expect something to be ready soon ish So what is Carpenter or what the intent of Carpenter is it replaces autoscalers like Cluster Autoscaler with a smarter and faster or hopefully simpler scaling solution as well It's kind of driven throughout the usual building blocks of Kubernetes So you kind of drive it through controllers and CRDs I'm going to show you examples later I have a demo ready up Hopefully the AWS gods will be with me today We all know what happened yesterday So what can go wrong right One of the biggest advantages of Carpenter would be it provisions nodes directly So it's actually not bound to any node groups or autoscaling groups in So when it provisions nodes it communicates directly with the API backend and provisions exactly the capacity you need to schedule all the unscheduled workloads that you're currently running When I say it's an intelligent high performance compute management solution what I mean by that is when it tries to find the compute it always looks at the cost as well So it tries to optimize not just for the capacity but also the minimal cost that would be required to satisfy the capacity that you need which I think is probably unique in that space or at least I'm not aware of a similar solution that would kind of take all those different dimensions in play We're going to look at two different dimensions or different things that Carpenter does on a high level So I'm not going to dive into very much technical details but what I want you to take away from this talk is Carpenter in a 10 foot view what it does it does scheduling and it does consolidation If you look at the scheduling first what does that mean it works in tandem with the Kubernetes scheduler It's not tightly bound to So for example if you're using something like Cluster Autoscaler you always have to use Cluster Autoscaler for the version of Kubernetes that you're running it on whereas Carpenter actually works independently of the Kubernetes version that you're It just communicates with the API backend There are two basic components so it uses Carpenter Core and Carpenter Provider Core is the core functionality whereas the provider is just the cloud provider specific implementation of the core Because we work in AWS my examples will be in but if you're working with other clouds the same principles would apply regardless of which cloud you work in So it works on a node claim basis so when the capacity is required it creates a node claim In AWS it just communicates with API directly initiates an EC2 Fleet API command to just provision nodes directly and then it just creates the node bindings ahead of time within the control plane so when the node comes up it's immediately bootstrapped and ready to go As you're going to see later it works really really quickly actually compared to other solutions Like I mentioned earlier it dynamically chooses and launches best suited compute resources so it supports both scaling up and down as well as in and out What I mean by that is it's adding capacity and removing capacity and it can also actually scale down to zero if required so if you don't run any other workloads it would just kind of take all the compute away As soon as you want to schedule something it would just add compute in When it does all of those things it actually uses native scheduling constraints so if you have PDBs defined so budget constraints or AZ affinity or other things it's kind of obeying all of those scheduling constraints so as it's trying to find compute it's kind of taking all of that into account as The second part is the compute consolidation you look at this I mentioned when you need new capacity that we go and provision it but it also knows how to consolidate existing capacity For example if you have Kubernetes running port scheduled and over time some of the ports might be scaled down there might be extra capacity available but it actually does It goes about and reschedules running ports into existing nodes or underutilized nodes and removes the nodes that can be removed and it's running those kind of simulations constantly within the controller to make sure that it's always kind of keeping up with the demand and compute available It can also launch new more cost efficient nodes as well So for example if at some point let's say your cloud provider changes pricing you can actually go provision cheaper nodes and reschedule all of your workloads to cheaper nodes and just remove the existing ones So it's always trying to kind of keep you running in the most optimal way that you can it does that it actually does it always with the least disruption So like I said it's always trying to reschedule the fewer available ports So when it creates disruption to the workloads it always tries to find the optimal path to kind of cause the least possible disruption for your workloads When you run ports or deployments or anything else It also is aware of drift detection So if your configuration drifts it will always try to re consolidate it back So it will always try to reconcile it to whatever your configuration is If something happened in the backend let's say I'm going to try to demonstrate it later So for example you could actually go and change the node version in the configuration It will automatically detect that oh your currently running nodes are older That's why you have the configuration Let's just go and replace all of them which is quite cool actually And there's another really cool thing in terms of compliance You can actually set the node expiration TTL It will always make sure that the nodes never run longer than X amount of time So let's say you always want to refresh your compute You can say recycle all the nodes older than three days or like a month And it will always just recycle those and make sure that they all run smoothly Right Let's quickly have a look how we set it up Like all sounds great but like how complicated it is to kind of set it up Like I mentioned earlier it consists of core and provider backend integration It all comes nicely packaged in the Helm chart On AWS you can actually use it as a managed solution using AWS EKS AutoMode It's something similar if you're familiar with GCP as GCP Autopilot I mean similar ish Like it gets you fairly close not quite there but you are not aware that it's happening under the Or you can manually go and set it up The process is quite straightforward How does it look like First of all obviously you have to set up IM and permissions for the carpet to run Then you go like I mentioned earlier go ahead and install the Helm chart for the controllers to run They're always deployed in high availability nodes They always have at least two or more of them running And then you go ahead and apply so called provisioners Like they changed the naming here It used to be called provisioners Now they kind of split it apart As you're going to see later it's node pool plot NAS class where you define what kind of compute you want to choose from And then just observe and scale right It's as simple as that Oh yeah It also supports more complex scenarios such as you can actually run multiple different configurations and put different weights on those and make sure that they're kind of used in let's say different tenants or different workloads for example And yeah it can actually run in parallel with CA as well So for example if you're currently running cluster autoscaler you can actually dedicate a specific part of compute that will use Carpenter and the rest of it if you just run in CA Let's say you want to kind of test it out and see how it works before you move everything across And obviously you can use all your favorite tools for provisioning such as Terraform CloudFormation EKS ETL All of that mostly has already implementation or configuration ready for you to use Right Shall we look at some hands on code Are you sure I have more slides if you want more slides I don't know if it's just the cake or you're just sleepy because of the long day Okay How do I get here Here we So first of all let's have a look what we have here I'm just going to show you what I'm currently running in my cluster It's running in AWS It's completely empty freshly provisioned The only thing that I have provisioned is Carpenter controllers just to kind of save some time on the demo And then the core DNS just comes with the So what we're going to do next is I'm just going to quickly deploy the provisioner part So that's going to be a node pool and node class As this deploys it's just a couple of CRDs I'm going to show you in a bit how they look like So as this applies I'm just going to quickly scroll up just to show you what has been applied So what is interesting here is what you can actually do is so as I said you have a node pool And then within the node pool you can actually define or specify you know how the nodes are going to be replaced So what I'm defining here is a node budget disruption budget And I said I always want to disrupt 20  of my compute at the same time So for example if I would go and replace all of the nodes it wouldn't replace all of them at once It would go like 20 20 20 and so on Next thing I will define I can say when I want to consolidate it I'm going to say only consolidate when empty or underutilized So you can define that policy as well Or you can actually say only consolidate when they're empty So you can actually fine tune it as much as you can I can actually specify what my limits are So my maximum CPUs will be 1 000 and I'm going to use 1 000 gigabytes of Irrelevant for our test but just to show you that you can actually go that parameter as well And what's actually quite interesting here as well is on the node class you can actually define so called One of the biggest advantages of Carpenter would be it provisions nodes directly
So it's actually not bound to any node groups or autoscaling groups in
So when it provisions nodes it communicates directly with the API backend
and provisions exactly the capacity you need to schedule all the unscheduled workloads that you're currently running
When I say it's an intelligent high performance compute management solution
what I mean by that is when it tries to find the compute it always looks at the cost as well
So it tries to optimize not just for the capacity
but also the minimal cost that would be required to satisfy the capacity that you need
which I think is probably unique in that space
or at least I'm not aware of a similar solution that would kind of take all those different dimensions in play
We're going to look at two different dimensions or different things that Carpenter does on a high level
So I'm not going to dive into very much technical details
but what I want you to take away from this talk is Carpenter in a 10 foot view
what it does it does scheduling and it does consolidation
If you look at the scheduling first what does that mean
it works in tandem with the Kubernetes scheduler
It's not tightly bound to
So for example if you're using something like Cluster Autoscaler
you always have to use Cluster Autoscaler for the version of Kubernetes that you're running it on
whereas Carpenter actually works independently of the Kubernetes version that you're
It just communicates with the API backend
There are two basic components so it uses Carpenter Core and Carpenter Provider
Core is the core functionality whereas the provider is just the cloud provider specific implementation of the core
Because we work in AWS my examples will be in
but if you're working with other clouds the same principles would apply regardless of which cloud you work in
So it works on a node claim basis so when the capacity is required it creates a node claim
In AWS it just communicates with API directly
initiates an EC2 Fleet API command to just provision nodes directly
and then it just creates the node bindings ahead of time within the control plane
so when the node comes up it's immediately bootstrapped and ready to go
As you're going to see later it works really really quickly actually compared to other solutions
Like I mentioned earlier it dynamically chooses and launches best suited compute resources
so it supports both scaling up and down as well as in and out
What I mean by that is it's adding capacity and removing capacity
and it can also actually scale down to zero if required
so if you don't run any other workloads it would just kind of take all the compute away
As soon as you want to schedule something it would just add compute in
When it does all of those things it actually uses native scheduling constraints
so if you have PDBs defined so budget constraints or AZ affinity or other things
it's kind of obeying all of those scheduling constraints
so as it's trying to find compute it's kind of taking all of that into account as
The second part is the compute consolidation
you look at this I mentioned when you need new capacity
that we go and provision it but it also knows how to consolidate existing capacity
For example if you have Kubernetes running port scheduled
and over time some of the ports might be scaled down
there might be extra capacity available but it actually does
It goes about and reschedules running ports into existing nodes or underutilized nodes
and removes the nodes that can be removed
and it's running those kind of simulations constantly within the controller
to make sure that it's always kind of keeping up with the demand and compute available
It can also launch new more cost efficient nodes as
well So for example if at some point let's say your cloud provider changes pricing
you can actually go provision cheaper nodes and reschedule all of your workloads to cheaper nodes
and just remove the existing ones
So it's always trying to kind of keep you running in the most optimal way that you can
it does that it actually does it always with the least disruption
So like I said it's always trying to reschedule the fewer available ports
So when it creates disruption to the workloads
it always tries to find the optimal path to kind of cause the least possible disruption for your
workloads When you run ports or deployments or anything else
It also is aware of drift detection
So if your configuration drifts it will always try to re consolidate it back
So it will always try to reconcile it to whatever your configuration is
If something happened in the backend let's say I'm going to try to demonstrate it later
So for example you could actually go and change the node version in the configuration
It will automatically detect that oh your currently running nodes are older
That's why you have the configuration
Let's just go and replace all of them which is quite cool actually
And there's another really cool thing in terms of compliance
You can actually set the node expiration TTL
It will always make sure that the nodes never run longer than X amount of time
So let's say you always want to refresh your compute
You can say recycle all the nodes older than three days or like a month
And it will always just recycle those and make sure that they all run smoothly
